docs.lead_paragraph: The wretchedness coming across our television screens from Louisiana has illuminated the way children sometimes pay with their lives, even in America, for being born to poor families. It has also underscored the Bush administration's ongoing reluctance or ineptitude in helping the poorest Americans. The scenes in New Orleans reminded me of the suffering I saw after a similar storm killed 130,000 people in Bangladesh in 1991 -- except that Bangladesh's government showed more urgency in trying to save its most vulnerable citizens.
docs.snippet: Hurricane Katrina underscores a much larger problem: the growing number of Americans trapped in a cyclone of poverty.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hour after hour, Antonia Lopez Paz said, her supervisor at the Koch Foods poultry plant here told women on the deboning line that production demands were so great that they could not go to the bathroom. Sometimes she developed acute pain because she could not go, Ms. Lopez said. And one time when another woman asked for permission, ''the supervisor took off his hard hat and told her, 'You can go to the bathroom in this,''' said Ms. Lopez, a Mexican immigrant who moved to this town in East Tennessee three years ago, lured by the company's promise of year-round work.

headline.main: Union Organizers at Poultry Plants in South Find Newly Sympathetic Ears

docs.abstract: Thriving unionization drive is growing in poultry plants in South, partly stemming from complaint by worker Antonia Lopez Paz that she was not permitted to leave her work station to use bathroom; United Food and Commercial Workers are organizing employees at two Koch Foods plants in Morristown, Tenn; union is one that broke away from AFL-CIO with promise of devoting far more energy to recruiting workers; as part of push, insurgent unions says they will seek to build deep community support among local houses of worship, political leaders and immigrant groups; most workers in area are Mexican and while they might seem ripe for organizing, labor's efforts face daunting obstacles in companies fighting back; many immigrants ultimately shy away from efforts, fearing retaliation; other organizing efforts in Southern states noted; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Two organizing drives aimed at poultry workers are among the early battles in the effort to reinvigorate labor.

docs.lead_paragraph: Everything went well at my annual checkup last year until the final few minutes. Perched on the exam table in a hospital gown, I was basking in my doctor's praise for how fit and healthy I kept myself at age 50, while she perused my medical records.

headline.main: Stunning News of a Tumor Serendipitously Discovered

docs.snippet: What does a patient do when a small tumor disrupts an otherwise uneventful annual checkup?

docs.lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez was taking batting practice last week in Seattle, where 40,000 people would soon remind him of how much they resented him. Joe Torre, the Yankees' manager, sneaked up on Rodriguez and booed him, just to set the mood. Torre would not have teased him like that last season, not when he was still learning his way around Rodriguez, the $252 million man who seemed like a tentative tourist in his first New York season. Now, it is safe to joke with him.

headline.main: Pinstripes A Better Fit This Season

docs.snippet: After an uneven debut in New York, Alex Rodriguez is more comfortable in the Yankees' clubhouse, more sure of his place in the team's hierarchy.

docs.lead_paragraph: As they have on past Labor Days, the nation's union leaders are vowing to reverse labor's decline, but that goal is made more difficult this year by the schism in the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and by the likelihood that striking mechanics at Northwest Airlines will suffer a bruising defeat. ''Labor is in some pretty tough rapids right now,'' said Harley Shaiken, a labor expert at the University of California, Berkeley.

headline.main: Amid Difficulties, Leaders Of Labor See Opportunity

docs.snippet: The nation's union leaders are vowing to reverse labor's decline, but that goal is made more difficult this year by the schism in the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. You're thinking about leaving your job, but first you want to explore your company's postemployment benefits. Should you ask your boss about them? A. Until the moment you hand over your resignation letter, it's best to keep your questions as subdued as possible, said Arlene Hirsch, a career counselor in Chicago. ''Just by asking questions of this nature, you can raise suspicions about your future plans and put yourself in an uncomfortable position,'' Ms. Hirsch said. Q. Which benefits should you be concerned about? A. In addition to compensating employees for unused sick and vacation days, some companies offer departing employees options such as continuing life insurance at their own expense and the ability to transfer money from defined-benefit pensions. By law, companies are required to allow employees to transfer tax-deferred savings plans to other accounts. In many cases, employees cannot claim employer-paid matching funds on retirement accounts until they have worked long enough to be ''vested'' in the company. Lonnie Pacelli, president of Leading on the Edge, a consulting firm in Sammamish, Wash., says that vesting periods vary by company and that it pays to be aware of the requirements. Q. What about health insurance? A. Under the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1986, employers with 20 or more employees who offer health care coverage are required to offer departing employees an opportunity to extend their health benefits. This law, known as Cobra, extends an employee's health benefits for up to 18 months beyond the last date of employment. The law says that employees have 30 days after their last day of work to request information about Cobra, and 60 more days after that to enroll. Employees must pay the premiums themselves, and premiums vary, depending on the kind of coverage your employer offers. Q. Where should you begin your search for answers? A. Terri Clark, director of human resources at the Art Institute of Las Vegas, suggests that you start with your company's employee handbook. Most companies distribute such handbooks during orientation for new employees, and update them periodically. Some companies have also put benefits information online or on corporate Intranets, she said. Generally, these supplement the handbook with links to information elsewhere, like the federal Labor Department's ''frequently asked questions'' page for Cobra, at dol.gov/ebsa/faqs/faq--consumer--cobra.html. Q. Should you consult former colleagues who have left the company recently? A. Sometimes the best resources are trustworthy friends. When Patrick Snow, a consultant in Bainbridge Island, Wash., decided to leave a corporate sales job in May, he called three friends to solicit advice about everything from continuing life insurance to cashing in unused vacation days. While the handbook offered general instructions for achieving these benefits, Mr. Snow's friends were able to provide him with specifics on whom to call, what to ask and how long the process would take. ''The employee handbook was good for a general overview, but it failed to answer some of my specific questions,'' said Mr. Snow, who left to start his own professional speaking business. ''Lucky for me, the information my buddies gave me enabled me to plan my exit strategy perfectly.'' Q. What are some other places to find reliable information? A. For financial expertise, particularly questions about rolling over money in a 401(k), many employees turn to accountants and financial advisers. You can also ask questions directly of insurance companies and benefits administrators, sometimes through a hot line. Sally Sidwell, senior vice president for operations at Automatic Data Processing, a company in Roseland, N.J., that provides payroll services and manages corporate benefit packages, said her organization regularly received e-mail messages and phone calls from employees of client companies with specific questions about Cobra benefits. ''A lot of times employees will call us directly with simple questions like, 'What am I going to have to pay?' or 'What does this include?''' she said. ''We understand that leaving a job is stressful, and we just try to help as best we can.'' Q. Should you ever approach your company's human resources department with your concerns? A. Human resources departments at some companies will respond gladly, even if you tell them you're thinking of leaving. But confidentiality is not required. With this in mind, Dana Law, an organizational development consultant in Bessemer, Ala., suggests corralling your curiosity, at least until you're certain you want to leave. ''Human resources professionals are there for employees, but it's also their job to worry about staffing levels,'' she said. ''If one department is running particularly short, or if a company is just looking to grow, these people have a responsibility to report any actions that seem suspicious of impending change.'' At some point, it becomes discourteous not to tell your company that you're contemplating leaving. Unveiling your plans may also work to your advantage: if some benefits are negotiable -- payment for sick days, for instance -- Ms. Law notes that it is prudent for employees to be on cordial terms at the end.

headline.main: Quitting? What to Know Before You Go

docs.snippet: If it's time to move on, first find out what benefits, if any, will follow you out the door.

docs.lead_paragraph: MATTHEW S. LEVATICH hovers intently over the shiny red-and-chrome Harley-Davidson motorcycle parked near his office. He is annoyed. A reporter has questioned the American purity of Harley cycles and Mr. Levatich, as the vice president in charge of procurement, is defending the faith. He is slowly circling an employee's bike, identifying the source of each visible part. True, the silvery, cylindrical shock absorbers, which rise like a ''V'' from the front-wheel axle, are from abroad. So are the aluminum wheels and spokes. That is because such things are not manufactured in the United States, or not as well here as they are in other countries. Various dashboard gauges are also imported. Once made in the United States, they are not anymore -- feeding the perception that American manufacturing is in decline.

headline.main: If You Can Make It Here

docs.snippet: The United States may not be the industrial dynamo it was a half-century ago, but reports of the death of American manufacturing are greatly exaggerated.

docs.lead_paragraph: Given the many burdens and growing expenses of daily life in New Jersey, this year's race for governor was expected to focus on concrete issues like suburban sprawl, the spiraling cost of health care and the state's property taxes. New Jersey's festering problem of political corruption also made it seem inevitable that both candidates would be irrepressible in extolling their cures for the state's ethical ills.

headline.main: In New Jersey, Candidates' Personal Finances Are Shaping the Campaign for Governor

docs.snippet: Both candidates in the New Jersey mayoral race find themselves on the defensive over questions about their personal finances.

docs.lead_paragraph: A risk management firm yesterday offered the first estimate of economic losses from Hurricane Katrina -- $100 billion -- and said that private insurance would probably cover less than a quarter of that. Federal money and charitable contributions may need to do the rest. Saying the damage already appeared far greater than expected, Risk Management Solutions in Newark, Calif., said that insured losses would range from $20 billion to $35 billion, much higher than the firm's initial estimate of $10 billion to $25 billion.

headline.main: First Estimate Puts Storm's Economic Toll at $100 Billion

docs.snippet: A firm estimated the losses from Hurricane Katrina at $100 billion and said that private insurance would probably cover less than a quarter of that.

docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's pace of job creation remained strong in the weeks before Hurricane Katrina, as the unemployment rate edged down to its lowest level in four years, the government reported on Friday. But the healthy data on job creation predated the hurricane, and there is a likelihood of at least a temporary slowdown caused by high fuel prices and damage to oil refineries, factories and transportation networks.

headline.main: Job Growth Stepped Up Its Pace In August

docs.snippet: The nation's pace of job creation remained strong in the weeks before Hurricane Katrina, as the unemployment rate edged down to its lowest level in four years.
